item.title: IRC Bot [framework]
item.dc:creator: @TeleNubby TeleNubby
item.description:
@TeleNubby wrote:

[quote=“Yz85Racer, post:17, topic:245074”]How do you expect us to post an informative, why should we bother. When he do, he replies with “write your own”. Too bad I already have.[/quote]What the hell Yz? Were you high when you posted this?

[quote=“Pwnd, post:6, topic:245074”][quote author=TeleNubby link=topic=321482.msg2542595#msg2542595 date=1227068524]
It reminds me of PIRCBot.
[/quote]Which was terrible, btw.[/quote]My point exactly.

[quote=“Yz85Racer, post:24, topic:245074”][quote author=zachera link=topic=321482.msg2542737#msg2542737 date=1227084211]

what the fuck, any GOOD irc client can connect to any RFC compliant IRC server, what makes IRC bots any different? irc clients have a gui and don’t handle user defined commands???

There’s only a few bots programmed by a team of developers. Not even my own bot written in PHP can last on every network, but I’ve been successful with a lot of networks so far.
[/quote]
I don’t see the difference between a client and a bot, one just doesn’t have a GUI displaying the information, and is used remotely.[/quote]
Wrong. A client does not require a GUI system and a bot does not have to be used remotely. A client simply means it takes what the server is giving it, processes it, and performs the corresponding task. A bot can be ran locally and it’s purpose is to perform tasks for you (automatically - see my definition of a client). In fact, they are very close to the same thing but we associate the terms with different meanings because of this community’s upsession with botnets.

Read full topic

item.title: IRC Bot [framework]
item.dc:creator: @lawl lawl
item.description:
@lawl wrote:

[quote=“zachera, post:16, topic:245074”][quote author=Pwnd link=topic=321482.msg2542652#msg2542652 date=1227075751]

from what i see, it doesn’t even comply to the IRC RFC.

You send JOIN on mode 001, this wouldn’t join any channel on a server that pings on connect (tlserv.com for example)

one more thing, ew.

You seem quite fond of yourself. Why don’t you write up your own, Cain_?
[/quote]Where did that come from…

If you read the post Cain_ made, you’d find that he
a) doesn’t like the code written by LIBRIUM,
b) prefers to send JOIN after the 001 status,
c) doesn’t like LIBRIUM’s code.

There’s absolutely nothing wrong with sending JOIN at the point of 001 status; not one bot can achieve a full successful connection, identify with the network, and establish a connection with a channel. All IRC server software is unique in its own way, for example, SlashDot.

Now, there’s no need to give this guy a hard time for his code. I’ve been talking with him on Ventrilo and he has some good plans for this bot of his. There’s no need for this nonsense about “He’s from moparscape” or how to “not write the code dastardly”. Post a respectful suggestion, not an egotistical suggestion.[/quote]
i hope you are trolling

Read full topic

There was nothing wrong with Cain_'s post. It WAS constructive criticism - maybe you should learn what constructive criticism means.

Anyways, lets keep the thread on topic folks.

Read full topic

item.title: IRC Bot [framework]
item.dc:creator: @z z
item.description:
@z wrote:

yakman:

[quote author=Cain_ link=topic=321482.msg2542748#msg2542748 date=1227084549]If you cannot write a IRC bot that is IRC RFC compliant, you really must suck

agreed,
iv managed to write a gui irc client in SCAR that complied with RFC,

the RFC for irc is very simple compaired to some other RFCs

as for you LIBRIUM

     static long START;
     static long FINISH;

     static String BOT_NAME, BOT_PASS;
     static String CHAN_NAME, CHAN_PASS;
     static int IRC_PORT;
     static String IRC_SERVER;

     boolean CONNECTED = false;

in java the naming convention is to only use capitalised names if the field is final, so it never changes.

                          String str = reader.readLine();
                          if(str == null) {
                                continue;

if you get null here, that means you’ve reached the End Of File, which means the server disconnected you or something, and you should close the connection

like i see you use System.exit() when you get the exit command, now although that will work fine, its quite confusing to anyone else reading your code, and perhaps you might be intrested in extending the bot so it reconnects later or connects to another server.[/quote]

We need more of these kind of posts.

Read full topic

item.title: IRC Bot [framework]
item.dc:creator: @yakman yakman
item.description:
@yakman wrote:

Cain_:

If you cannot write a IRC bot that is IRC RFC compliant, you really must suck

agreed,
iv managed to write a gui irc client in SCAR that complied with RFC,

the RFC for irc is very simple compaired to some other RFCs

as for you LIBRIUM

     static long START;
     static long FINISH;

     static String BOT_NAME, BOT_PASS;
     static String CHAN_NAME, CHAN_PASS;
     static int IRC_PORT;
     static String IRC_SERVER;

     boolean CONNECTED = false;

in java the naming convention is to only use capitalised names if the field is final, so it never changes.

                          String str = reader.readLine();
                          if(str == null) {
                                continue;

if you get null here, that means you’ve reached the End Of File, which means the server disconnected you or something, and you should close the connection

like i see you use System.exit() when you get the exit command, now although that will work fine, its quite confusing to anyone else reading your code, and perhaps you might be intrested in extending the bot so it reconnects later or connects to another server.

Read full topic

item.title: IRC Bot [framework]
item.dc:creator: @z z
item.description:
@z wrote:

Yz85Racer:

I don’t see the difference between a client and a bot, one just doesn’t have a GUI displaying the information, and is used remotely.

Bots are clients, in the server’s view. I thought Cain_ referred to clients as IRC clients with GUI’s (xchat, mIRC, PJIRC, etc.). From my experiences, I believe bots are clients and can be controlled by other clients, depending on the bot’s setup. To get a true IRC with the 100% protocol down and getting everything working can take a long time if you build your own methods for parsing the buffer that is sent by the IRC server. What we’re dealing with here is someone who wants to build a bot (or Zombie as it seems to be in his code), which has commands setup for other clients to use for their convenience, and it seems to me that he’s not going to use a library, so he has to follow the RFC’s.

I think I was interpreting Cain_'s message on the “JOIN after 001” wrong, since RFC is the most important part of writing an IRC bot, and I completely forgot about them.

Read full topic

item.title: IRC Bot [framework]
item.dc:creator: @Yz85Racer Yz85Racer
item.description:
@Yz85Racer wrote:

[quote=“zachera, post:20, topic:245074”][quote author=Yz85Racer link=topic=321482.msg2542721#msg2542721 date=1227082964]

How do you expect us to post an informative, why should we bother. When he do, he replies with “write your own”. Too bad I already have.

It has been a long time since I’ve seen an informative post on this forums. I suggested Cain_ to write his own because he doesn’t like this one, but I guess I should really be encouraging Cain_ to suggest a better method of writing it rather than saying what is wrong with it.

I can tell you now Cain_ has wrote his own, quite a fucking lot of them too.
[/quote]

It has been a long time since I’ve seen an informative post on this forums. I suggested Cain_ to write his own because he doesn’t like this one, but I guess I should really be encouraging Cain_ to suggest a better method of writing it rather than saying what is wrong with it.

Cain_ should have some informative input with some suggestions on what he should be doing, rather than talking about what’s wrong with his code.[/quote]
Well, they’re both just as good. Cain_ was showing him what he did wrong when he picked his code apart, it isn’t Cain_'s obligation to spoon-feed the OP with the correct answer. It is the poster’s responsibility to then research and find what he is doing wrong, and if he is struggling with this I am sure Cain_ would tell him why.

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @Yz85Racer Yz85Racer
item.description:
@Yz85Racer wrote:

[quote=“zachera, post:16, topic:245074”][quote author=Pwnd link=topic=321482.msg2542652#msg2542652 date=1227075751]

from what i see, it doesn’t even comply to the IRC RFC.

You send JOIN on mode 001, this wouldn’t join any channel on a server that pings on connect (tlserv.com for example)

one more thing, ew.

You seem quite fond of yourself. Why don’t you write up your own, Cain_?
[/quote]Where did that come from…

If you read the post Cain_ made, you’d find that he
a) doesn’t like the code written by LIBRIUM,
b) prefers to send JOIN after the 001 status,
c) doesn’t like LIBRIUM’s code.

There’s absolutely nothing wrong with sending JOIN at the point of 001 status; not one bot can achieve a full successful connection, identify with the network, and establish a connection with a channel. All IRC server software is unique in its own way, for example, SlashDot.

Now, there’s no need to give this guy a hard time for his code. I’ve been talking with him on Ventrilo and he has some good plans for this bot of his. There’s no need for this nonsense about “He’s from moparscape” or how to “not write the code dastardly”. Post a respectful suggestion, not an egotistical suggestion.[/quote]
